answers.content_html: Either the south pole of magnet 1 is closer to the north pole of magnet 2 or the north pole of magnet 1 is closer to the south pole of magnet 2.
answers.feedback_html: Repulsion always occurs between the same poles of two magnets.

answers.content_html: Either the south poles of both the magnet 1 and magnet 2 are closer to each other or the north poles of both the magnet 1 and magnet 2 are closer to each other.
answers.feedback_html: The north pole of a magnet is always repelled by the north pole of the other magnet, whereas the south pole of a magnet is always repelled by the south pole of the other magnet.

stem_html: If two magnets repel each other, what can you conclude about their relative orientation?

answers.content_html: The directional lines present inside and outside the magnetic material that indicate the magnitude and direction of the magnetic force.
answers.feedback_html: The field lines flows in a proper direction which indicates the direction of magnetic force and the density of the field lines at a particular region indicates the magnitude of magnetic force at that region.

answers.content_html: The directional lines present inside and outside the magnetic material that indicate the magnitude of the magnetic force.
answers.feedback_html: Both the magnitude and direction of a magnet can be determined from its field lines.

answers.content_html: The directional lines present inside the magnetic material that indicate the magnitude and the direction of the magnetic force.
answers.feedback_html: The field lines are also present outside the magnetic material.

answers.content_html: The directional lines present outside the magnetic material that indicate the magnitude and the direction of the magnetic force.
answers.feedback_html: The field lines are also present inside the magnetic material.

answers.content_html: Yes, the magnetic fields from the two north poles will point in the same directions.
answers.feedback_html: The magnetic fields from the two north poles will not point in the same direction.

answers.content_html: Yes, the magnetic fields from the two north poles will point in opposite directions.
answers.feedback_html: This would cause the needle to not be magnetized.

answers.content_html: No, the magnetic fields from the two north poles will point in opposite directions.
answers.feedback_html: As a result, the magnetic fields will cancel each other out and the needle will not be magnetized.

answers.content_html: No, the magnetic fields from the two north poles will point in the same directions.
answers.feedback_html: The magnetic fields from the two north poles will not point in the same direction.

stem_html: If you place a small needle between the north poles of two bar magnets, will the needle become magnetized?

answers.content_html: Magnetize the needle by holding it perpendicular to a bar magnet’s north pole and pierce the cork along its longitudinal axis by the needle and place the needle-cork combination in the water. The needle now orients itself along the magnetic field lines of Earth.
answers.feedback_html: A needle cannot be used as a compass needle when it is magnetized by holding it perpendicular to a bar magnet’s north pole.

answers.content_html: Magnetize the needle by holding it perpendicular to a bar magnet’s north pole and pierce the cork along its longitudinal axis by the needle and place the needle-cork combination in the water. The needle now orients itself perpendicular to the magnetic field lines of Earth.
answers.feedback_html: Remember, a needle cannot be used as a compass needle when it is magnetized by holding it perpendicular to a bar magnet’s north pole.

answers.content_html: Magnetize the needle by holding its axis parallel to the axis of a bar magnet and pierce the cork along its longitudinal axis by the needle and place the needle-cork combination in the water. The needle now orients itself along the magnetic field lines of Earth.
answers.feedback_html: This is the correct procedure to construct a compass needle.

answers.content_html: Magnetize the needle by holding its axis parallel to the axis of a bar magnet and pierce the cork along its longitudinal axis by the needle and place the needle-cork combination in the water. The needle now orients itself perpendicular to the magnetic field lines of Earth.
answers.feedback_html: The procedure is correct but remember the needle will orient itself along the magnetic field lines of Earth.

stem_html: Given a bar magnet, a needle, a cork, and a bowl full of water, describe how to make a compass.
